about_the_game:
ling Hun Ost:


Ling Hun is an Asian-style game and as such, its music had to have that oriental essence.
Made digitally with traditional Chinese instruments, with the occasional synthesizer and with a lot of love, Gerard Montero has managed to take us to the East. We could imagine a feudal zone where, very calmly, we are introduced to each of the traditional instruments that gradually appear in each area of the game and culminate it with an ending where the emotion and rhythms, despite following a calm trend , they place us in a state of emotional intoxication that elucidates the end of a fantastic adventure.



we Talk About Each Song:

01 - Jia - Ling Hun

"Jia" means house in Chinese and as it is the initial area of the game, Gerard wanted to convey a lot of calm. The feeling of home, where peace exists and freedom is breathed.

02 - Lu Shan - Ling Hun

Here Yun begins to be able to use a new mechanic that greatly expands the gameplay of the title, with which the music must match, using a traditional Chinese string instrument called "Erhu" it generates a mystical and epic atmosphere to welcome the new challenges.

03 - Shan Qiang - Ling Hun

The traditional flute is introduced, with a sound that transmits freedom but also deception, since it is an area in the game where nothing is what it seems, it is transmitted through a changing melody but that remains at a relaxed pace.

04 - Ju Yan - Ling Hun

In the Ju Yan area, the game already begins to have several mechanics with which to interact and master, but despite this it continues to offer calm gameplay, therefore, another string instrument is introduced to give a touch of calm with long sounds and melodic that are accompanied by moments of relative tension when using "stacatto" techniques to play said instrument and give a melodic and defined rebound to the song.

05 - Kua Shan - Ling Hun

This song introduces several ancestral instruments such as Buddhist bells and traditional drums that are usually used in religious ceremonies and rituals. To maintain the calm of the title, these instruments have been used gradually and with spaces to give the listener a state of constant calm despite a certain noise resulting from the instruments themselves.

06 - Simiao Yan - Ling Hun

Here instruments that have already been heard before begin to mix, among them we can once again hear the "Erhu" with its sound as characteristic and recognizable as the "Yanqing", two string instruments that sound so different that it makes them Combined, even in the distance, they generate a melody that can easily transport you to oriental fantasy.

07 - Rongtai - Ling Hun

We again find a combination of several instruments, in essence we find several traditional flutes along with drums. In this case Gerard has played with the panning of said instruments and their vibrato (the panning refers to which side, right or left, certain sounds can be heard) to generate a vibrant and dissonant atmosphere that makes you understand that a certain thing is beginning to approach. closure of the adventure.


08 - Main Menu Theme - Ling Hun:
This is the theme that we can hear as soon as we turn on the title and it immediately conveys to us, with drums, a feeling of greatness and the importance of what we are about to reveal. In the case of being the first time playing, this grandiloquence is given by Yun's story with Zorro.

09 - Extra - Ling Hun

Since an extra phase has been made to discover all the collectibles within the game, the music of this phase could not be other than one of the previous phases but in reverse. Well, since this extra phase is intricate, far-fetched and more difficult than many of the previous ones, something appropriate had to be done to demonstrate and transmit said madness.

reviews:
“always accompanied by a very relaxing soundtrack and a beautiful and sober artistic section, I also allowed myself to remember those moments with a certain nostalgia, it allowed me to see in Ling Hun a small shadow of what great games are capable of achieving.”
NaviGames

“The game's sound is simple, but really authentic. The soundtrack is made by Gerard Montero, one of the creators of the title, who has put all his effort into composing melodies that seem straight out of feudal Japan.”
Punto De Respawn
short_description: Ling Hun is an Asian style game and so it's music is inspired with the chinese traditional instruments. You'll be able to relax hearing the "Erhu", the "Yanqing", Bamboo flutes, traditional percussion and much more. All of it in a relaxed and cozy way for you to enjoy.
